video.title: Python Django Web Framework - Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn the Python Django framework with this free full course. Django is an extremely popular and fully featured server-side web framework, written in Python. Django allows you to quickly create web apps.

💻Code: https://github.com/codingforentrepreneurs/Try-Django

⭐️Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) 1 - Welcome
⌨️ (0:01:14) 2 - Installing to Get Started
⌨️ (0:05:02) 3 - Setup your Virtual Environment for Django
⌨️ (0:14:39) 4 - Create a Blank Django Project
⌨️ (0:18:54) 5 - Setup Your Code Text Editor
⌨️ (0:22:27) 6 - Settings
⌨️ (0:29:58) 7 - Built-In Components
⌨️ (0:33:57) 8 - Your First App Component
⌨️ (0:42:34) 9 - Create Product Objects in the Python Shell
⌨️ (0:46:18) 10 - New Model Fields
⌨️ (0:52:52) 11 - Change a Model
⌨️ (0:59:27) 12 - Default Homepage to Custom Homepage
⌨️ (1:04:48) 13 - URL Routing and Requests
⌨️ (1:10:23) 14 - Django Templates
⌨️ (1:16:50) 15 - Django Templating Engine Basics
⌨️ (1:24:00) 16 - Include Template Tag
⌨️ (1:26:49) 17 - Rendering Context in a Template
⌨️ (1:33:21) 18 - For Loop in a Template
⌨️ (1:37:01) 19 - Using Conditions in a Template
⌨️ (1:42:17) 20 - Template Tags and Filters
⌨️ (1:48:59) 21 - Render Data from the Database with a Model
⌨️ (1:59:55) 22 - How Django Templates Load with Apps
⌨️ (2:06:50) 23 - Django Model Forms
⌨️ (2:14:16) 24 - Raw HTML Form
⌨️ (2:25:33) 25 - Pure Django Form
⌨️ (2:35:30) 26 - Form Widgets
⌨️ (2:41:29) 27 - Form Validation Methods
⌨️ (2:48:59) 28 - Initial Values for Forms
⌨️ (2:51:42) 29 - Dynamic URL Routing
⌨️ (2:54:26) 30 - Handle DoesNotExist
⌨️ (2:56:24) 31 - Delete and Confirm
⌨️ (2:58:24) 32 - View of a List of Database Objects
⌨️ (3:00:00) 33 - Dynamic Linking of URLs
⌨️ (3:01:17) 34 - Django URLs Reverse
⌨️ (3:03:10) 35 - In App URLs and Namespacing
⌨️ (3:07:35) 36 - Class Based Views - ListView
⌨️ (3:10:45) 37 - Class Based Views - DetailView
⌨️ (3:15:38) 38 - Class Based Views - CreateView and UpdateView
⌨️ (3:21:23) 39 - Class Based Views - DeleteView
⌨️ (3:24:02) 40 - Function Based View to Class Based View
⌨️ (3:27:15) 41 - Raw Detail Class Based View
⌨️ (3:30:31) 42 - Raw List Class Based View
⌨️ (3:33:32) 43 - Raw Create Class Based View
⌨️ (3:26:03) 44 - Form Validation on a Post Method
⌨️ (3:37:58) 45 - Raw Update Class Based View
⌨️ (3:41:13) 46 - Raw Delete Class Based View
⌨️ (3:42:17) 47 - Custom Mixin for Class Based Views

Course from Coding for Entrepreneurs. Check out their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWEHue8kksIaktO8KTTN_zg

Also, check out the Coding For Entrepreneurs website for more great content: https://www.codingforentrepreneurs.com

--

replies.author: Miles Whitaker
replies.text:
yep, me too. Had to install a slightly newer version of Django,  delete db.sqlite3, re-migrated, and then re-run the server. And that fixed it for me.

    1: >   pip install django==2.1.5
    2: Delete db.sqlite3
    3: >  python manage.py makemigrations
    4: >  python manage.py migrate

    5: >  python manage.py runserver

topLevelComment.author: Harry Lockheed
topLevelComment.text:
In his section called, "Initial Values For Forms": 2:49:02 - 2:52:08, he doesn't show you the change that he made off screen, but for me to get that section about rendering initial data to work.... I had to got to the urls.py page under trydjango/, add "render_initial_data" to the line that has:

"from products.views import product_detail_view, product_create_view, render_initial_data".

Finally, replace the path with "render_initial_data":

"urlpatterns = [
    path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
    path('', home_view, name='home'),
    path('contact/', contact_view),
    path('aboutus/', aboutus_view),
    path('product_detail/', product_detail_view),
    path('product_create/', render_initial_data)

]"


Anyone else that went through this course step by step, can you confirm this, or did I miss something and just do more work than I needed? I'm a noob and trying to learn, but that seems like the way to get it to work like he showed. I figured if it might save someone else the trouble that I should make mention of it.

replies.author: SimplyCodingWithAlex
replies.text: @Hubert Budny If new to Django, after each topic the mentor covers in this video pause the video and try to re-create what he did but with different text or something extra etc. Take it slow, and make sure you understand why and how it works. Continue this as learn new topics. Dont try to overwhelm yourself by. watching like hours of this video because there is a lot of content to digest ad Aarav Jain mentioned take it slow it better

    system(path_to_env)
    system('python manage.py runserver')

topLevelComment.author: atiktook
topLevelComment.text: I learned a lot from this video and appreciated it. He seems really confidence and has a energy to bring people’s attentions. However I felt like he didn’t prepare much for the lecture since he must be used to doing things with Django. He makes the example for the exercise, these weren’t often proper for the cases(not saying every example must be perfect). For example when he demonstrated ‘capfirst’ filter he could have typed a string starting with lower case to show the change by the filter but he didn’t. And this isn’t the unique case as you would probably know while following instructions. Since this video was made for beginners so the mindful examples could be more helpful to remember.

replies.author: Prashanth
replies.text:
@Sebastian Here's an example.

Lets say you're using a library. You start developing your application using this version. Lets say 2 months from now, a new version drops with better features, more functionality, etc and you want to use it. So you update it.  However, this new version may have changed certain core functionalities and now your app doesn't work, since it uses features from a prior version that no longer exist. If you use a venv, you can have one venv with the old version that you can still use for development and another venv with the newer version.

Another reason to create venvs is when you install libraries that depend on various other libraries, ex: pytorch, tensorflow, so that there are no dependancy conflicts.

That's why the best practice is to leave python as is once installed and create a venv for every project.

Took me a few retries but I finally finished this walkthrough. This course felt a bit rough around the edges, but I think that was mainly an issue of speed; with the course set to 0.75x playback speed I found that very manageable. I wish the course were organized just a tad bit different, I generally prioritize a certain kind of logical progression over the speed to running code. This guy did a great job and I think succinctly achieved his objective of compacting an introductory django course into 4 hours of content. I'm  just a django in 14 hours kind of gal. ;)

replies.author: Krish Kittur
replies.text:
When it says "detects no changes" this can mean one of two things:
1. You didn't save the file, and you need to save it
2. You didn't actually change the file at all, or if you were to make a migration it would be identical to a migration that already exists.
It's not an error... more of just a "note" or "status check"

topLevelComment.author: SSNUTHIN
topLevelComment.text:
RESOLVED! Solution below.
Can anyone explain why products\views.py completely changes between 2:27:48 and 2:51:08? I was trying to backtrack because the def render_initial_data is not working in my project. I went to check the official github and it does not include the render_initial_data definition at least not in products\views.py. Im going to try to keep going and hope for the best. 

Any insight would be welcome. Happy Coding!

Update:

Its subtle but after scrapping my code and starting over, I realized what was happening is that for whatever reason the lesson skipped parts. Particularly the portion where 'render_initial_data' is added to the urls. It is also confusing because at this point in the tutorial the 'products\views.py' has been cleaned out on his code editor. Remember to update the urls file (in 'products\urls.py' if youre putting it there, or in the '<root>\path_to\urls.py' if you're using the root of the project) by importing and setting a path for 'render_initial_data'. From there, you should be able to continue with the tutorial. I hope this was helpful!

topLevelComment.author: SSNUTHIN
topLevelComment.text:
RESOLVED! Solution below. 

I'm having a weird issue in regards to the validation technique around 2:45:18 where I am not getting the validation error raised on either chrome or firefox despite using the exact same code. I will acknowledge I am using a newer version of python(3.9) and django (3.1.3) so I'd appreciate knowing if it's just different, but looking into the documentation seems to say otherwise. 

Has anyone else had this issue? If so were you able to remedy it? Thanks to anyone who takes the time to answer. 

Happy Coding!

Update: My error had to do with syntax. Per Dajngo 3.1 documentation (https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.1/ref/forms/validation/) :

"The clean_<fieldname>() method is called on a form subclass – where <fieldname> is replaced with the name of the form field attribute. This method does any cleaning that is specific to that particular attribute, unrelated to the type of field that it is. This method is not passed any parameters. You will need to look up the value of the field in self.cleaned_data and remember that it will be a Python object at this point, not the original string submitted in the form (it will be in cleaned_data because the general field clean() method, above, has already cleaned the data once)."

self.cleaned_data has to occur in reference to a subclass and my indentation indicated otherwise. Make sure "def clean_title" is nested 4 spaces right of "ProductForm".

topLevelComment.author: Michael Rothkopf
topLevelComment.text:
If you get 
Creating virtual environment...ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'virtualenv.seed.via_app_data'
then follow these steps:
1. Copy and paste this folder into the folder bar in file explorer.
%appdata%\python\python38\site-packages\virtualenv\seed\embed
2. Right click on the "via_app_data" folder
3. Click copy.
4. Copy and paste this folder into the folder bar in file explorer.
%appdata%\python\python38\site-packages\virtualenv\seed\embed
5. Right click on empty space
6. Click paste.
Run pipenv install again and it works perfectly. This is because virtualenv changed its system so that it's "import virtualenv.seed.embed.via_app_data" instead of "import virtualenv.seed.via_app_data".

topLevelComment.author: GwresYnKernow
topLevelComment.text:
This was a good tutorial, and as someone with a couple of days experience with Django, was just what I was looking for. One thing that did bother me though is that, especially early on when covering Templates, the examples were SO vague and SO generic as to be distracting. I totally get that you didn't want to go too in-depth with "actual" code, but creating lists of random numbers and variables called "abc" is a little irritating.
I understand why you didn't want to start off by using the backend data right off the bat, as it's easier to explain the context first, but it would've been better (IMO) to use  a list full of made up products, and tried to make it look halfway presentable, before then going "ok, let's replace these placeholders with actual data from the database", instead of having lists called 'abc' full of random numbers.
And who decides to explain chaining by chaining together capfirst and upper?  :p
It just felt a bit thrown together and rushed, like you'd just turned the camera on and were like "oh hey, these are things you can do". Again, it was a great tutorial, especially for free. I just think it could've been a lot better with a bit of thought put into it, and with an actual project in mind instead of just arbitrary data.

topLevelComment.author: The Rook
topLevelComment.text:
TLDR: Use pip3, not pip when installing django.


I'm a beginner and much of this is foreign to me, but it seems that with python 2's end of life, many things that were fine in the past are not well and good now (April 2020). The top comment at the time of writing this stresses one issue with 2.0.7, but even installing django was a massive undertaking for a baby steps kinda guy like me. 


The upshot is to make sure you're using pip3 and python3 instead of just pip and python. Nowhere in the documentation (that I've found) does it say to use pip3, but its a must-do in 2020.

I'm using Django v3.0.2. When I got to section 21 on Rendering Data from the Database with a Model, I kept getting an error that Product class didn't contain a method called objects. I had to create a manager class to work around this as follows:

class ProductManager(models.Manager):
     def create_product(self, title):
          product = self.create(title=title)
          return product


In the Product class, I added a line that says object = Product Manager()


Now, things seem to be working.

topLevelComment.text: Three times at the Change a Model I've had same  problem when tried to add a product through the admin console. Upon save, I get an error that says 'No such table: main.auth_user__old'. First time I began from scratch and rebuilt carefully up to there. I got the same error a second time. On third attempt I went to StackOverflow and followed suggestion there. topLevelComment.text:
If you get an operational error when trying to save your new product (around 40:00), do the following:


pip install django==2.1.5


It will automaticall uninstall your 2.0.7 version of django and reinstall django at the newer version.
This newer version works and products can then be added. An older version of SQLite seems to have caused this problem.

topLevelComment.author: Ray Silva
topLevelComment.text:
According to much research and reading on Python, Stack Overflow, articles, etc. setting up is nowhere as simple as he makes it sound. On Mac there's a pre-installed version of Python that you should not mess with. Installing specific version he suggests I found on SO needs brew, but it can confuse versions it didn't install. Involved process to clean prior installations and avoid messing with the Mac installed one. Even then, with brew updated, I couldn't install pyenv or pyenv-virtualenv, much less Python version 2.7.15 as he suggests. 


He sounds like he knows his stuff, but explanations are missing. I had set up Python 3.8 with Django on Windows for some earlier tutorials. Tried here to use my Mac and follow him, but couldn't even get started. Much research and went back over his intro several times. Still dead in the water. It would be great if he could actually explain what he knows.

replies.author: Ray Silva
replies.text: Oh, by the way, about using Django 2.0.7, running his command (pip install django==2.0.7) returns: "Error: no matching distribution found for django==2.0.7!" Also got depracation warning to upgrade from python version 2.7, so I will now go back and try upgrading to latest version of python. I hope that will still permit following the tutorial, and maybe installing Django 2.0.7.

replies.author: Ray Silva
replies.text:
Finally was able to install Python version 2.7.15, but I'm confused. I think he said to make sure you install the same versions as him. He had Python 2.7.15 as his default, and 3.65 as his python3. Don't know if he wanted us to install 2.7.15 (maybe he makes that clear later).


He did say when creating the virtual environment that if you had 3.6 as your default (python -V) the command had to include '-p python3 .' and if your default (python -V) is 3.6, then omit that portion; but again not explaining at all. After lots of googling, stack overflow, etc., I ran with the omission, leaving the period. Nothing worked. I had to actually name an environment as part of the command. The way he did it was not clear and didn't correspond to any other explanation I was able to find searching. 


My installed default python -V was 2.7.10. Nothing worked. I tried installing 2.7.15 as python2. Then, python2 -m virtualenv <newenvname> worked. Activating it with source /bin/activate also didn't work. source newenvname/bin/activate worked for me. Again, a lot of researching and precious little explanations.


Look, he's impressive, and I want to follow this tutorial. I already did the Django Documentation tutorials. They may be thorough, but they are not clear either. I'm sticking with this.

topLevelComment.author: 20 minute gamer
topLevelComment.text:
Is there any problem with pycharm? why people wont use it ?
pycharm always starts in virtual environment and you don't even need to start venv?
but people still use cmd why?

replies.author: Joseph
replies.text: There isn't a problem with it, but using cmd means you can use whatever tool you want (technically the same is true of any IDE/text editor but that's just extra hassle). I also encourage you to not use venv but pipenv, it is "easier" but most importantly it is the preferred way to use virtual environments now and to install django and run the environment is as simple as "pipenv install django" "pipenv shell".  The most important feature of it is that it keeps track of things you install and uninstall for the virtual environment and keeps them in a file, meaning you can create a dependency doc and create environments from it really quick and easy.

topLevelComment.author: Kaan Atakan
topLevelComment.text: The first half of your video was great and I enjoyed it overall. But I'd like to make some constructive criticism: I would have much rather seen how to do a slug based lookup, or a bit about front-end users, or some real world validation, etc... than watching you redo the views 3 times using different methods. This is especially no good for beginners. Too many design choices can be absolutely paralyzing for a beginner. They will spend too much time deciding which to use when they could be writing some app logic and getting real experience. And if you focus on one method they will become more competent and confident in it. It'll also be more memorable. Perhaps teaching the first two methods could be justified, but there really was no need to rewrite the whole thing with raw class based views. Do beginners really need that info? At most it deserved was a mention that you could also do it that way.

topLevelComment.author: Haitham Badarin
topLevelComment.text:
Here's how to install django on Windows 10: 
1. Install python 
2. After Installing python,  Run Windows Powershell  as an administrator and type the following command: pip install virtualenvwrapper-win 
3. Then create a virtual environment for your project: mkvirtualenv myproject 
4. now Django can be installed easily using pip within your virtual environment.
In the command prompt, ensure your virtual environment is active, and execute the following command: 
pip install django

topLevelComment.author: Hylke Nicola
topLevelComment.text: For people getting an error when they click p[roducts after changing fieldtypes in the product class: When you do a makemigration and then migrate it doesnt actually do anything. I discovered this with the command "manage.py inspect db". After i deleted the db and the migraton files it somehow just restores them and does tries an old migration and since you have changed the class you'll get an error. So first of all you need a primary key in every table, so at the top of your class ad a field called id like so: id = models.AutoField(primary_key=True), the quit the server in the other terminal with ctrl+c, then run the makemigrations command, and then run the migrate command. You'll notice it does a bunch of changes with a list of processes and OK behind them. Then run the server again and you are good. Also it is a good practice to stop the server before you delete crucial files like datastores schemes or db's. Keep that in mind.. Happy coding!

topLevelComment.author: Jeremiah Mullane
topLevelComment.text:
Here's a question I can't seem to find the answer to:

Let's say I have a directory I am planning to use django from, and I create a virtualenv there, I activate it, and I work a bunch, and then I deactivate it later.

Does it persist? Do I just have to reactivate it, and everything is as I left it?

What if I accidentally built it twice? Does it reset that directory's dependencies? Do I then I have to reinstall all the packages I had there?

What if I keep building more and more virtualenvs in every directory? Is there some downside to this?

I am trying to get a firm grasp on how virtualenv behaves. I understand the point of it, but if someone could tell me the answer to this I'd be appreciative.

replies.author: Jeremiah Mullane
replies.text:
Pretty sure I understand now. Creating the venv creates subfolders in that directory that hold the settings for my virtual environment, and running activate will use the settings in those subfolders.
If you remake the venv from scratch, it will overwrite the subfolders with new settings. so I should  just leave it alone unless I want to change something.
No need to make multiple venvs as long as I am working out of subfolders of wherever the venv was created.

topLevelComment.author: Kelly Davis
topLevelComment.text: I'm 40 mins in and there's a habit you have that makes it next to impossible to follow with out pausing and re-watching over again.      its a simple fix for you.     Close out or minimize duplicate terminal sessions.   You have layered consoles on your screen which makes it difficult to follow which window you are typing in.   I have to pause -rewind 5 secs and re-watch.     I'd think you have 2x as many views if you simply clean up that nasty habit.   Other than that,   I like your format and how you are breaking things down.    I will admit.   I've gone from follow mode (meaning follow along and building as you go)   to just listening because its hard to track what window you are working in.

topLevelComment.author: Lux Nox
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone that doesn't already have python3 installed, when you get to the point of pip installing django, if it sends an error saying it can only find 1.whatever versions of django, just use pip3 install django==2.0.7 . This will ensure that a python3 compatible version of django is installed.

If you're on mac and dont have pip3 just, brew install pip3.

topLevelComment.author: Extension Flexxin
topLevelComment.text:
At 51:37 the code(note the code isn’t on the screen, only the price field)

price = models.DecimalField(decimal_places=2, max_digits=10000) 

allows the usage of the character “ e “ in the price field, could anyone elaborate on why that is the only character that can be used other than numbers. Is that a Django bug? Or a python bug?

replies.author: Koga Master
replies.text: @TheEpicGamer'e' refers to exponential. Used when you have a really long number. Example from above user, 5.35e11 = 5.35×10¹¹

replies.author: TheEpicGamer
replies.text: @A Commenter That too maybe. Could be either

replies.author: A Commenter
replies.text: I think it's because saying 5e11, for example, means 5*10^11 which is an  easier way to type large numbers.

replies.author: shawn jacobsen
replies.text: e represents a number (~2.72) and can be used as proper syntax for representing this number. It's Euler's number and involves natural logarithms. Pretty interesting stuff if you're into that sorta thing.

replies.author: TheEpicGamer
replies.text: I have no clue, but my guess is because e is technically a decimal. Its an irrational number (one that never ends like pi) and can be used for calculations. It's also known as Euler's number.
